bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, January 19, 1923

div1.p: Hanson suspects that the reported case of Weil's disease, reported in Guayaquil, may be yellow fever. He believes that the International Health Board should investigate.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, January 19, 1923
div1.opener:
Book
Clarac
Intrinsic Incubator
3014 Winfield Ave.,
Baltimore, Md. January 19, 1923.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have just received your letter of the 18th and very
much appreciate the fact that you are always ready to reply in spite of your
mucho ocupado tiempo. Yes the time is short for the outline I have made and
as I stated in the card which I sent you today I find that I shall have to
eliminate a lot of things which ought to be interesting and worth while pre-
senting. I shall not follow Halstead's example, in fact I shall not take up more
than about 40 minutes of their time in this talk. If they want to prolong it
by asking questions, that is another question. I shall not even be able to cover
what I indicated on my card in the time allowed. Between now and Monday I shall
think over very carefully what I may be able to present in the time, most like-
ly taking mainly the points which you have commented on.

My reference to Clarac is in “GRALL et CLARAC, TRAITÉ de PATHOLOGIE
EXOTIQUE” -- DENGUE, FIÈVRE JAUNE?
CHOLÉRA MALADIE DU SOMEIL,
published in 1912.

I. - Historique et Géographie Médicala, Par A. Clarac. This
chapter begins on page 21. What he says of your observation is, “Or, des
observations faites en 1898 par le Dr. H.R. Carter semblaient indiquer
que l'agent de la fièvre jaune, comme celui du paludismo, n'etait pas
capable de transmettre la maladie avant qu'un délai déterminó se fût
écoulé à partir du moment eù cet agent avait eu l'occasion de s'infector
sur un malade.” page 38 beginning with fifth line. Again on page 51
the last paragraph on page in speaking of the interval between the
first and secondary cases he says; “Neus avens signalé déjà les re-
marquables observations faites par Carter à Orveed et Taylor en 1898.
Carter avait pu relever exactement l'intervalle qui s'écoule entre
l'introduction d'un malade amaril dans un hameau isolé, jusqu'
alers indemne de fièvre jaune, et le primier cas qui suit cette intro-
duction. Cet intervalle est régulièrement de deux à treis semaines. A
partir de ce moment, la manifestation de nouveaux cas n'obéit plus
à aucune règle de tempa.”
he quotes you again in regard to the length of the period of incubation in
man on page 81, second paragraph. If I come over Sunday afternoon I will bring
my book with me in case you care to read this article of Clarac's.

I am sorry for the subpoena because it would ahve lent me great moral
Dr. H.R. Carter
2
January 19, 1923
support to have you present.

I do not know how safe it is to lay stress on 19 with all the Weil's
disease which is reported from Guayaquil. Ever since you last wrote me about
the reports of this disease from Ecuador I have been a bit uneasy. You remember
that it was Weils disease which Dr. Zuniga was diagnosing in Paita before you
came to Peru, (i.e. Spirocetosis ictero hemorraghica) and it seems to me very
important that we should have some very reliable information as to the true
nature of the disease in Guayaquil. In fact if I were running the yellow fever
section for the I.H.B., I think I would either go in person, or I would send
some one down the west coast to make a very careful systematic survey all the
way down. This person should be one who really knows yellow fever when he sees
it. These people down there are not going to make an error in diagnosis in
favor of yellow fever, by that I mean they are going to continue making the
diagnosis of Weil's disease until they are forced to make the other. I am not
suggesting myself for the job, but I know of no one who could so well do this
as I can, for the simple fact that I am still officially the Director of Public
Health for Peru, and I could call in both Columbia and Ecuador on a friendly
visit basis. I have a very cordial invitation from Dr. Pareja to visit Guayaquil,
and Columbia and Peru are very friendly. The only importance of Columbia would
be in case this were no Weil's disease there could be some temporary feeding
foci from Columbia which would be annoying but not serious.

If you are to busy to talk Sunday do not hesitate to say so, I am going
to Washington to see what information I can get about the roads to the south, as
I may start for Florida by auto at the end of next week or the first part of
the week following, all depending on the weather and reports on the roads.

Since I may have the opportunity to see you Sunday P.M. I shall not write
more at present. With best wishes from all the Hanson family,
